channel.title: ASF Jira
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [THRIFT-953] make check fails in TransportTest.cpp
item.description:
make -j2 check fails on my box with the following:

g++ -DHAVE_CONFIG_H -I. -I../../.. -I../../../lib/cpp/src -I/opt/local/include   -g -O2 -MT TransportTest.o -MD -MP -MF .deps/TransportTest.Tpo -c -o TransportTest.o TransportTest.cpp
TransportTest.cpp: In function 'void set_alarm()':
TransportTest.cpp:381: error: 'SA_ONESHOT' was not declared in this scope
TransportTest.cpp: In function 'void parse_args(int, char**, Options*)':
TransportTest.cpp:1028: error: 'CLOCK_REALTIME' was not declared in this scope
TransportTest.cpp:1028: error: 'clock_gettime' was not declared in this scope
mv -f .deps/AllProtocolTests.Tpo .deps/AllProtocolTests.Po
g++ -DHAVE_CONFIG_H -I. -I../../.. -I../../../lib/cpp/src -I/opt/local/include   -g -O2 -MT ZlibTest.o -MD -MP -MF .deps/ZlibTest.Tpo -c -o ZlibTest.o ZlibTest.cpp
make[4]: *** [TransportTest.o] Error 1
make[4]: *** Waiting for unfinished jobs....
mv -f .deps/ZlibTest.Tpo .deps/ZlibTest.Po
make[3]: *** [check-am] Error 2
make[2]: *** [check-recursive] Error 1
make[1]: *** [check-recursive] Error 1
make: *** [check-recursive] Error 1

Only affects HEAD, not 0.5.0; seems related to latest facebook changes.
item.environment:
Darwin – 10.4.0 Darwin Kernel Version 10.4.0: Fri Apr 23 18:28:53 PDT 2010; root:xnu-1504.7.4~1/RELEASE_I386 i386
i686-apple-darwin10-g++-4.2.1 (GCC) 4.2.1 (Apple Inc. build 5664)

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
See also THRIFT-847 for what's potentially more breakage related to the most recent facebook changes: the cpp client is just plain broken.

I get the following error message for a client I just wrote:

Running in client-only mode
Running byte tests
terminate called after throwing an instance of 'apache::thrift::transport::TTransportException'
  what():  Base TTransport cannot write.
Abort trap

(the first two lines are normal output of the said client).

The interesting bits of the client are the following, and look to me like a straight copy of the tutorial:

void client_thread_func(void) {
  cross::server local;

  boost::shared_ptr<apache::thrift::transport::TTransport> socket(
      new apache::thrift::transport::TSocket("localhost", 9090));

  boost::shared_ptr<apache::thrift::transport::TTransport> transport(
      new apache::thrift::transport::TBufferedTransport(socket));

  boost::shared_ptr<apache::thrift::protocol::TProtocol> protocol(
      new apache::thrift::protocol::TBinaryProtocol(transport));

  // Setup random number generator
  boost::mt19937 gen;
  boost::uniform_int<> dist(0, 48);
  boost::variate_generator<boost::mt19937&, boost::uniform_int<> > rand(gen, dist);

  // Setup thrift client
  cross::SimpleClient remote(protocol);
  transport->open();

  // Run byte tests
  apache::thrift::GlobalOutput("Running byte tests");

  std::vector<int8_t> bytes;
  bytes.push_back(0);
  for (std::vector<int8_t>::size_type i = 0; i < 16; i++)
    bytes.push_back(rand());

  for (std::vector<int8_t>::size_type i = 0; i < bytes.size() - 1; i++) {
    for (std::vector<int8_t>::size_type j = i; j < bytes.size(); j++) {
      int8_t local_value = local.addBytes(bytes[i], bytes[j]);
      int8_t remote_value = remote.addBytes(bytes[i], bytes[j]);
      assert(remote_value == local_value);
    }
  }

  transport->close();
}

In particular, it works for 0.5.0, but NOT for HEAD.

SA_ONESHOT is a synonym for the POSIX-correct SA_RESETHAND (see http://lxr.oss.org.cn/ident?i=SA_ONESHOT, click on a few of the arch-specific headers).

clock_gettime (and CLOCK_REALTIME) are linux-only functions. Instead, use time(NULL) to get current time, feed that to srand and use rand() to seed our own (better) random number generator.

David, thoughts?

I'm wondering, that clock_gettime is linux-only... see http://www.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/009695399/basedefs/time.h.html

However, srand/rand is a better alternative and being more POSIX conform is good!

from my perspective, this should be committed!

already tested on GNU/Linux Debian Lenny

The first hunk looks great.

The second hunk should not delete that comment.

clock_gettime is defintely POSIX. Weird that this doesn't work on your system. However, using time is probably fine. The only downside that I know of is that if you run the program twice in one second, you get the same seed. However, this program takes more than one second to run, right?

There is no need to call srand and rand. You can just use the time as the seed.

I assumed it wasn't POSIX since it wasn't on Mac OS X: http://juliusdavies.ca/posix_clocks/clock_realtime_macosx_faq.html – mea culpa, looks like just more madness from Apple.

v2 addresses both of David's comments.

BTW, something I should have mentioned earlier, it doesn't actually make the test pass on my machine, just allows it to compile again. It fails to build on my machine:

/bin/sh ../../../libtool --tag=CXX   --mode=link g++  -g -O2   -o TransportTest TransportTest.o libtestgencpp.la ../../../lib/cpp/libthriftz.la -l:libboost_unit_test_framework.a -lz -lpthread 
libtool: link: g++ -g -O2 -o .libs/TransportTest TransportTest.o -Wl,-bind_at_load  ./.libs/libtestgencpp.a /Users/moosefish/ports/src/thrift-svn-3/lib/cpp/.libs/libthrift.dylib ../../../lib/cpp/.libs/libthriftz.dylib -l:libboost_unit_test_framework.a -lz -lpthread
ld: library not found for -l:libboost_unit_test_framework.a
collect2: ld returned 1 exit status
make[4]: *** [TransportTest] Error 1
make[3]: *** [check-am] Error 2
make[2]: *** [check-recursive] Error 1
make[1]: *** [check-recursive] Error 1
make: *** [check-recursive] Error 1

But if I link it by hand and then run it, it dies anyway:

$ g++ -g -O2 -o .libs/TransportTest TransportTest.o -Wl,-bind_at_load  ./.libs/libtestgencpp.a /Users/moosefish/ports/src/thrift-svn-3/lib/cpp/.libs/libthrift.dylib ../../../lib/cpp/.libs/libthriftz.dylib /opt/local/lib/libboost_unit_test_framework.a  -lz -lpthread

$ ./.libs/TransportTest 
Running 265 test cases...
unknown location:0: fatal error in "CoupledZlibTransportsT<CoupledMemoryBuffers>::test_rw(1048576, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0)": std::exception: zlib error: buffer error (status = -5)
TransportTest.cpp:474: last checkpoint
unknown location:0: fatal error in "CoupledZlibTransportsT<CoupledMemoryBuffers>::test_rw(262144, rand(1, 4096), rand(1, 4096), 0, 0, 0)": signal: SIGSEGV, si_code: 0 (memory access violation at address: 0x00000000)
TransportTest.cpp:474: last checkpoint

*** 2 failures detected in test suite "TransportTest"

However those look like completely orthogonal errors, so I recommend v2 be committed and I'll keep investigating when I have time. For the record, my machine is:

$ port list | grep -i boost
boost                          @1.44.0         devel/boost
boost-build                    @2.0-m12        devel/boost-build
boost-gil-numeric              @1.0            devel/boost-gil-numeric
boost-jam                      @3.1.18         devel/boost-jam

$ uname -a ; g++ --version
Darwin -- 10.4.0 Darwin Kernel Version 10.4.0: Fri Apr 23 18:28:53 PDT 2010; root:xnu-1504.7.4~1/RELEASE_I386 i386
i686-apple-darwin10-g++-4.2.1 (GCC) 4.2.1 (Apple Inc. build 5664)
David, this version addresses your time resolution concern by XOR'ing the tv_sec and tv_usec (microseconds) values from gettimeofday. Lemme know.

This gets TransportTest to compile and run successfully (with no failures) on my box:

$ port version ; echo ; port list | grep -i boost ; echo ; uname -a ; echo ; g++ --version
Version: 1.9.1

boost                          @1.44.0         devel/boost
boost-build                    @2.0-m12        devel/boost-build
boost-gil-numeric              @1.0            devel/boost-gil-numeric
boost-jam                      @3.1.18         devel/boost-jam

Darwin -- 10.4.0 Darwin Kernel Version 10.4.0: Fri Apr 23 18:28:53 PDT 2010; root:xnu-1504.7.4~1/RELEASE_I386 i386

i686-apple-darwin10-g++-4.2.1 (GCC) 4.2.1 (Apple Inc. build 5664)

This patch depends on v3-fix-usage-of-linux-only-functions.patch – David, can you test this one on a linux machine? Shouldn't break anything – but without it my version of libtool barfs, specifically, it rejects -l:libboost_unit_test_framework.a:

$ libtool -V
Apple Computer, Inc. version cctools-782
, tested with the latest two patches on GNU/Linux Debian Lenny

The gettimeofday change is fine, though that function has been deprecated in favor of clock_gettime.

I'd prefer if we could come up with a solution that wouldn't require further forking of ax_boost_base. Is it possible to get this changed pushed back upstream, or even use the autoconf macro archive's test for boost unit test?

That's all fine and dandy, but gettimeofday works everywhere, and
clock_realtime doesn't.

I'd need to investigate the latter (though it does sound like the
right thing). Would you be fine committing this as is and filing a bug
against me to investigate?

just found another place within Thrift's codebace with similar issue:

#if defined(HAVE_CLOCK_GETTIME)
 #include <time.h>
#elif defined(HAVE_GETTIMEOFDAY)
 #include <sys/time.h>
#endif // defined(HAVE_CLOCK_GETTIME)

see: http://svn.apache.org/viewvc/thrift/trunk/lib/cpp/src/concurrency/Util.cpp?view=markup
my preference is v3-fix-usage-of-linux-only-functions.patch in combination with the above mentioned ifdef from Util.cpp
Sounds good to me. I'd also be fine with just using gettimeofday. Deprecated though it may be, it's not going away any time soon.
Applied as is, I'll file cleanup bugs against myself to sanify the gettimeofday thing codebase-wide and to push our boost macros upstream.
